results.title: Look at Wales
results.brief_description: A selection of the tourist attractions in the towns, villages and countryside of Wales. Includes scenes of the Royal National Eisteddfod, and landscapes of mountain and valley contrasted with the bustling civic centre of Cardiff.

results.creator_credit: Pamela Eagles, Donn Clauscen, Dianne Milwright and Miles-Milwright

results.title: Look at me
results.brief_description: This video graphically illustrates in dramatic style the problem facing a teenager whose dog is run over and in urgent need of help. Nick is hearing impaired. An alert young man with limited speech, he is devastated when his dog, Smoky, his closest friend, is run over. In his efforts to get help he grabs Gavin, a passing cyclist, and desperately tries to make him understand his problem; but Gavin thinks Nick is a “right Wally”. “Look at Me” is a compelling introduction into the everyday problems facing the hearing impaired.

results.title: Look at life: under your feet
results.creator_credit: Rank Film Productions and British Information Services
results.brief_description: An unusual angle on London indicating the wealth of history concealed under crowded streets. Looks at many of the underground services which play an important role in the life of the city; the great electricity tunnels under the Battersea Power Station and the Thames; the water mains and the labyrinth sewers; the Postal Service tube railways; the Chancery Lane silver vaults; and a 700 year old carmelite crypt. Narrated by Tim Turner.

results.title: Look alive!
results.brief_description: Designed to motivate an awareness of electrical safety amongst tradespeople, the film is fast-paced and amusing rather than merely instructional. It covers the use of protective clothing, safety equipment, power tools and safety procedures.

results.title: Look again at gulls
results.creator_credit: Anthony Clay, Royal Society for the Protection of Birds Film Unit and Gateway Film Productions
results.brief_description: A study of British gulls which, while they are so common that most birdwatchers ignore them, are so complex that some zoologists spend a lifetime studying them. Narrated by Michael Rodd.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Anthony Clay, Royal Society for the Protection of Birds Film Unit and Gateway Film Productions

results.title: Look & book: arts & entertainment video directory
results.creator_credit: Ron Cummings, Gary Gray, Irene Krumins and Raceplay
results.brief_description: A video catalogue of forty-five groups and artists who are available to perform at all types of venues including school functions and fetes. A wide range of performers are shown, covering such areas as: magic, mime, clowns, rock, country, folk and bush bands, cabaret, comedy, jazz and blues, guitars, piano and chamber orchestas, puppet theatre, dance and movement, vocal peformance and poetry.

results.title: Lonnie's day
results.brief_description: We become part of Lonnie’s world as we follow him through a typical day - at home in a high rise apartment complex, at school and in the streets of a large city neighbourhood. A sensitive film that shows the stresses, pleasures and family life of an eight year old African American boy.

results.title: Longtime companion
results.creator_credit: Norman Rene, Stan Wlodkowski and Samuel Goldwyn Company
results.brief_description: One of the first American films to deal with the AIDS epidemic, Norman Rene’s ‘Longtime companion’ traces the lives of a group of young American gay men living and dying in the time of AIDS. The film’s starting point is 1980 when the disease is first mentioned in the New York Times. Initially referred to back then as ‘Gay-Related-Immune-Disorder’, the early whispers of a mysterious ‘gay cancer’ hardly rated a mention. Based on a Craig Lucas play, the film documents the rapid spread of the disease throughout the eighties as these once healthy men are suddenly faced with their own mortality. The film and play takes its title from the refusal of the New York Times to acknowledge homosexual partners in their obituary column, preferring the more discreet term ‘longtime companion’. At the time of the film’s release it was criticized for being too discreet in its attempt at dealing with homosexuality and AIDS, and was conservative enough for cast member Bruce Davison to win the most mainstream of accolades, a Best Supporting Actor at the Oscars. The film’s sentimental finale drew the most fire, particularly from a very politicized Queer movement, who saw it as innocuous and conservative (three years later Jonathan Demme’s ‘Philadelphia’ would also draw the same criticism). In retrospect however the film’s tenderness for it’s characters and it’s earnest attempt to chronicle the devastating effect of the epidemic ultimately accumulates an emotional resonance that moves, even in it’s final wish-fulfillment coda. Cast includes: Campbell Scott, Dermot Mulroney, Michael Schoeffling, Mary Louise Parker.
